projects.summary: Option 2 — Design an experience for students to discover orientation events and craft a visual system to accommodate different types of events: sports, music, visual arts, social groups, and volunteering events. Provide high-fidelity mocks for searching, browsing, and viewing the details for these different events.

projects.title: A.S. Graphic Studio
projects.description: Redesigned and developed a new website for Associated Students Graphic Studio.
projects.summary: One of my first projects as Associated Students Graphic Studio's new webmaster was to revamp their 9-year-old website. I gave the site a visual refresh that closer aligned with our fun brand and used modern web development practices to improve content management.

projects.title: Stride Career Fair
projects.description: Website for a design-centric career fair hosted by Design at UCSD.
projects.summary:
As part of Design at UCSD’s leadership board, I worked alongside my cross-functional team to put together UC San Diego’s first design-centric career fair. Stride follows a unique career fair format that allows design students to better showcase their work and portfolios.

In collaboration with one of our visual designers, I developed the event website. I also assisted our graphic studio in creating visual collateral.

intro.title: Partner

projects.title: Design Camp
projects.description: Website for a workshop series focused on building your design skills outside of the classroom.
projects.summary: Design Camp is a three-part workshop series hosted by Design at UCSD that focuses on building your design skills outside of the classroom. I worked with a visual designer to build a visually compelling website that helped the event series gain traction.

projects.title: Design Frontiers: Intuit
projects.description: Website for a day-long design sprint hosted by Design at UCSD in partnership with Intuit.
projects.summary:
Design Frontiers is a series of design sprints hosted by Design at UCSD that showcases the application of design thinking to fields beyond traditional design, such as education and healthcare. For our Fall 2018 event, we partnered with Intuit to allow students to tackle real product design challenges alongside leading designers in the financial software space.

As Design at UCSD's web developer, I collaborated with our visual designers to build the website and also facilitated the design sprint the day of.

intro.title: Teammates
intro.content: Nancy Bui, Lauren Choy, Lucy Xu

projects.title: Burow
projects.description: Desktop web app that helps users find the perfect new home to move to.
projects.summary: Burow is a desktop web app that helps users find the perfect new home to move to. With a focus on price, walkability, and school rating, users can easily pinpoint neighborhoods within their target cities that suit their needs.

intro.title: Key Roles
intro.content: Led the design and development of the landing page and co-led the brand design. UX was done as a team.

intro.title: Key Skills
intro.content: Prototyping, brand design, web design, web development (HTML, CSS, Sass, React)

intro.title: Teammates
intro.content: Aman Gupta, Joel Sequeira, Jared Suasin

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Popular real estate apps, such as Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin, start by asking users for a location. Users then use metrics such as price and number of beds/baths to sort through the returned listings. Additional research could then be done to find walkability, safety scores, and more for an address. This user flow works great for those looking for homes in specific neighborhoods, but what if you wanted to choose a neighborhood based on a metric?

sections.title: Solution
sections.content:
Our team's solution reversed the user flow of traditional real estate apps to allow users to scan cities at a macro level. It does this by focusing on price, walkability, and school rating, and sorting neighborhoods within a city by these criteria. Because these scores can vary dramatically between neighborhoods, this approach benefits users who know little about their new city.

Existing solution:
Enter location → receive listings → use criteria to sort through listings

Proposed solution:
Enter city → choose criteria → receive sorted neighborhoods

sections.title: Storyboarding
sections.alt: Mark and Sarah want to move their family from New York to California.
sections.beforeCaption: To better understand our target users, we started by drafting two storyboards.

sections.alt: Jim is a student looking for an apartment for his internship in the Bay Area this summer.

sections.title: Competitive Analysis
sections.alt: Landing pages of Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin
sections.afterCaption: Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin all use real estate photos, generous negative space, and safe typefaces to create a clean, polished look. While a professional appearance increases credibility, it comes with the tradeoff of looking impersonal and detached.

sections.title: Brand Design
sections.beforeCaption: Since our app only sorts neighborhoods and does not show listings or collect any personal data, we could afford to forgo the professional look. So, we took the opposite approach and established a cozy, welcoming atmosphere.
sections.quote: Burow—Dig around and find the neighbourhood that fits your needs!
sections.afterCaption: To produce a homey feel, we used the theme of burrowing animals and gravitated towards warm earth tones and typefaces with gentle curves.

projects.title: Design at UCSD
projects.description: Visual designer, web developer, and student leader at the largest pre-professional design community on campus.
projects.summary: Since November 2017, I’ve been a student leader at the undergraduate design community Design at UCSD. I served as a visual and brand designer up until June 2018, where I designed marketing collateral, co-lead visual design workshops, and evolved brand identity. I now spearhead all our web development projects as our web developer.

intro.title: Roles

Visual and Brand Designer (Nov 2017 – June 2018)
Web Developer (June 2018 – Present)

sections.title: Our Mission
sections.quote: To establish an open community of aspiring designers, to inspire creative confidence, and to ease students into industry.

sections.title: Web Projects
sections.beforeCaption: As our web developer, I collaborate with our visual design team to create websites for events, workshops, and email campaigns. Two of the biggest projects I've worked on so far are Stride Career Fair and Design Frontiers: Intuit.

projects.title: Salesforce × TravelBoss
projects.description: Reimagined a presentation template for upcoming business meetings.
projects.summary:
The task at hand was to reimagine a slide deck to create a visually compelling presentation template for upcoming meetings between Salesforce and the fictitious company TravelBoss, whose brand is similar to Airbnb.

Note: This was completed as a timed challenge.

sections.title: Problem + Solution
sections.afterCaption: The original presentation slides were uninspiring and lacked identity. Through careful brand analysis, I crafted a bold and compelling template that embodied the energy and spirit of both the Salesforce and TravelBoss (Airbnb) brands.

projects.title: ERGO
projects.description: Web app that combats the discomfort and injury that results from a sedentary lifestyle.
projects.summary: Our work environments can work against us. Many of us, especially students and office workers, sit our lives away; this has been linked to high blood pressure, obesity, worse mental health, and more. ERGO is a web app that combats the discomfort and injury that results from a sedentary lifestyle by periodically alerting users to stretch. Designed to work across many different spaces, ERGO is unique in that it introduces exercises that use the everyday objects around us, inspiring users to rethink their interactions with their spatial environments.

intro.title: Roles
intro.content: Led the brand design and development of the HTML prototype. Interaction design was done as a team.

intro.title: Key Skills
intro.content: Needfinding, storyboarding, wireframing, rapid prototyping, visual design, web development

sections.title: Design Brief
sections.content: When the spaces we regularly navigate become a part of our routines, we fail to recognize how we interact with them. Our team's goal was to reassess the interactions between users and their environments to discover how these interactions could be used to fulfill unmet user needs. In particular, we were interested in human behavior within work settings and how the use of computers could contribute to successes and breakdowns.

sections.title: Needfinding + Personas
sections.content: We observed 3 participants in their respective work environments and discovered that wellness was a common concern between them. Using the data we collected, we constructed personas that encapsulated our target audience: people who regularly experience long periods of physical inactivity.

personaList.description: Tony is a college student who is studying all night for an exam he has the next day. He becomes immersed in his studies and doesn't realize when his posture worsens and his eyes begin to feel strained. Tony needs a way to be reminded to take breaks and relieve physical stress.

Steve is currently studying for the MCAT using his test prep books. He is also a full-time lab technician, so he only has time to study at home before and after work. He is worried about the effects of a sedentary lifestyle, but the ergonomic tips he finds online cater to office workers who use computers. Steve needs tips and exercises that are applicable to his environment.

Wanda works in an office and experiences discomfort from sitting at her desk all day. She has tried a few ergonomics apps before but is sometimes too lazy to get up and perform stretches. Wanda needs a tool that can successfully encourage her to be more active.

sections.title: Ideation
sections.content:
To guide us towards a solution, we reframed the insights and pain points above into opportunities:

  • How might we remind users to take breaks and stretch after long intervals of inactivity?
  • How might we accommodate users in different spaces or users with different tools at their disposal?
  • How might we make being active enticing to users?
  • Additionally, how might we accommodate users with disabilities or injuries?

sections.title: Solution
sections.content:
Our solution was an ergonomics app that periodically notifies users to perform a stretch or exercise. It would be unique in that it takes into account the user's setting and suggests stretches that are applicable to the devices they're using. These suggestions could then be customized for accessibility and further flexibility. This approach sets the app apart from its competitors by providing users a more fun, personalized stretching experience.

To encourage users to actually perform the stretches provided by the app, we decided to include a social feature. Once a user is done setting up a routine, they could share their settings with their friends or coworkers so that they all receive the same notifications. By turning stretching into a group activity, the app takes advantage of the power of social influence to get users to be more active.

sections.title: Storyboarding
sections.alt: Storyboard: Natalie and Robb successfully use ERGO to reduce their respective pains
sections.beforeCaption: To explore the different scenarios in which our app could be used, my team then drew up storyboards.

sections.title: Rapid Prototyping
sections.beforeCaption: We then created two prototypes and had participants walk through several use cases on each one. Our first prototype (left) starts by asking users what device they're working on, while the second prototype (right) asks users where they are working.
sections.afterCaption: An issue we discovered while testing was that a user's device does not tell us much about their environment (e.g. a laptop can be used anywhere). So, we decided to move forward with our second prototype. View paper prototypes.

sections.title: Revisiting the Brief + Redesign
sections.content:
Upon revisiting the design brief, we realized we had strayed. While our solution provided users with exercises that were relevant for their location and setup, this was not an environmental interaction in itself. So, how might various work spaces be used to help their respective occupants reach their end goals?

Our revised solution was to have our application suggest stretches that use surrounding objects. Environments would be grouped with other environments based on the objects that are common to them. We redefined our categories as follows:

  1. Office — possibly a cubicle or small space; stretches can utilize desks and chairs
  2. Home — wide array of furniture at user's disposal, disruptive exercises are not a concern
  3. Indoor (public) — libraries, coffee shops; stretches are seated and more discreet
  4. Outdoor — open space; stretches can utilize larger objects such as trees or poles, exercises can be more extensive (e.g. running)

sections.title: Wireframing
sections.alt: App flow when logged in and logged out
sections.beforeCaption: Next, we created wireframes to visualize the flow of our app.

sections.title: Brand + Visual Design
sections.beforeCaption: Our decision to go with a light UI was made carefully after considering that working and studying often take place during the day and in well-lit spaces. We incorporated pops of a vibrant blue-green gradient to set an energizing and refreshing mood that reflects ERGO's main goal: to encourage wellness.

sections.title: HTML Prototype
sections.content:
With our app flow and branding established, we were able to start developing our live prototype. With the help of tools such as

  • Node.js (Express + Handlebars)
  • Sass

we built a responsive HTML prototype. Over the next 6 weeks, we implemented core functionalities and refined our app using feedback from users. Check out our live prototype and our Github repository.

sections.title: User Testing
sections.alt: New home page with how to get started tips and environment descriptions
sections.beforeCaption: One of the biggest problems we discovered while user testing is that ERGO had poor visibility of system status. To resolve this issue, we made labels more informative and added more descriptions throughout our app.

sections.alt: New setup page with environment name in the title
New person icon and bookmark icon
sections.beforeCaption: Another problem we had was that users did not find our icons intuitive, namely our Log In and Favorites buttons. We replaced our Log In icon with the universal icon for Profile, a person, and decided to rename our Favorites page to Bookmarks. Stretch routines are saved using URL parameters, so we decided this new title would be more fitting.
sections.afterCaption: After implementing these changes, we continued user testing and received positive feedback.

sections.title: Final Design
sections.content: View our live prototype to check out our final design!

projects.title: Remember That I Love You
projects.description: Poster design for UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@'s 27th Pilipin@ Cultural Celebration.
projects.summary: For UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@'s 27th Pilipin@ Cultural Celebration (PCC), I served on the Official Cultural Cabinet as a graphic designer. PCC is one of the org's biggest events, and includes dancing, singing, and live theater. This year's production, titled Alalahanin Mong Mahal Kita (Remember That I Love You), tackled themes of LGBTQ, mental health, and family. I created a poster and accompanying marketing collateral that helped draw in 400+ attendees.

projects.title: Portfolio
projects.description: Built my portfolio from the ground up to showcase my evolving set of visual design and web development skills.
projects.summary: To showcase my adaptive skill range, I took on the role of both the designer and developer to build my portfolio from the ground up.

intro.title: Development Tools
intro.content: HTML, CSS, Sass, Node.js (Express + Handlebars), jQuery, Gulp

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: As an undergraduate student looking to apply for UI/UX design and engineering internships, having an online portfolio was essential. The task at hand was to create a website to accompany my resume, where I’d present my projects and provide potential employers easy access to my online platforms. However, I faced an inconvenience: I had switched into UC San Diego’s human-computer interaction program at the beginning of my third year. With less formal experience and project courses under my belt than my peers, how do I build a compelling portfolio? If not through UX projects, in what other ways can I convey my understanding of the human-centered design process?

sections.title: Research + Solution
sections.content:
To begin answering these questions, I combed through the portfolios of seasoned UI/UX designers to figure out what made them successful in landing positions. Through this competitive analysis, I confirmed that it was essential to have a strong sense of visual design and a unique brand. The defining characteristic of a solid portfolio, however, was the designer’s ability to communicate their thought process and approach through story. Some of my favorites are amandashearon.com, melaniedaveid.com, and chris-liu.me.

Because storytelling plays such a fundamental role in UX, I decided to include graphic design projects in my portfolio to provide more insight into my process. I particularly chose those that involved branding, as they presented many opportunities for me to walk through my design decisions. While these graphic design projects do not explicitly showcase my UX skills, they illustrate how I use research to derive visual solutions that satisfy client needs.

On top of communicating my understanding of design thinking, I also needed to demonstrate my skill set in both visual design and coding. The solution here was obvious: design and code my own site.

sections.title: Ideation
sections.content: Content before design. There’s nothing worse than coding an entire website, only to realize at the end that it doesn’t accommodate your content. I knew I’d be including diverse projects in my portfolio, and thus the layout for my case study pages would contain various elements. Content I needed to account for included basic text and image sections, but also color palettes and PDFs. Moreover, these sections would be chapters of an overarching story. With this in mind, I began sketching out layouts that had clearly defined content blocks.

sections.afterCaption: Coming up with a design turned out to be the most difficult part of this project. I jumped into high-fidelity mockups way too quick, and found myself stuck. I explored several different concepts, but felt that none of them captured myself as a designer. I didn’t want to just get the job done; my work is an extension of myself, and I needed to set the right visual tone. So, I took a step back to think about my brand and scrapped everything for a fresh start.

sections.title: Final Design
sections.beforeCaption: As a huge fan of minimal design, I wanted the layout of my portfolio to be clean and simple. I decided the perfect way to achieve this while also expressing my graphic design roots was to draw inspiration from print portfolios and editorial layouts, which often consist of generous white space and creative typography. For my color palette, I stuck with neutrals and used a deep peach accent sparingly to ensure that my projects are centerplace. View mood board.

sections.afterCaption: This design had the intentionality that my previous iterations lacked. The clean layout sets a relaxed mood, while the offset headings, casual typeface, and bright accent add a hint of playfulness.

sections.title: Development
sections.content:
Because I'm interested in UX engineering, it was key that I build my portfolio from scratch. My first time around, I used my self-taught knowledge of Sass, Bootstrap and AngularJS to achieve a smooth, responsive site. My web development skills have since come a long way, and I found my initial code to be messy and inefficient. My portfolio also did not have functionality that benefited from using a framework as complex as AngularJS. After receiving formal education, I performed a complete overhaul of my website. Tools I used to develop the current version of my portfolio are:

  • Node.js (Express + Handlebars)
  • Sass
  • Gulp (Nodemon, BrowserSync, Sass, Autoprefixer)

The biggest change between my first and second iteration was my switch to the Handlebars templating engine. Since the bulk of my portfolio is a set of similarly laid out case studies, it was the perfect tool. By templating this page, I significantly reduced clutter and made adding new projects painless. I also wanted my website to be pixel-perfect, so I decided against using Bootstrap to allow for more control. View on Github.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: The final product had an aesthetic brand, incorporated a layout that facilitated storytelling, and was supported by efficient code. Overall, it demonstrates my skill set as a visual designer, UX designer, and UX engineer. I am now ready to apply for internships. :^)

projects.title: How Far I'll Go
projects.description: Shirt design for UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@’s 27th annual high school conference.
projects.summary: Themed after the animated Disney film Moana, UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@'s 27th Annual High School Conference was held February 3rd, 2018. These high school conferences are coordinated in collaboration with the Student Promoted Access Center for Education and Service and aim to empower high school students to pursue higher education. This year, I was invited to create a shirt design for the event.

sections.title: Photos
sections.alt: Pair of funcilitators sharing a bagel

projects.title: Ourstory Gala
projects.description: Spearheaded the brand design for UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@’s 30th Anniversary Ourstory Gala.
projects.summary: Kaibigang Pilipin@ (KP), translated to "Friendship of Filipin@s," is a student-run organization at UC San Diego that aims to educate the community about Pilipin@ culture. Every five years, KP hosts their Ourstory Gala, a celebration held to commemorate the organization and its accomplishments. I worked closely with the event coordinator to craft a unique identity for their 30th Anniversary Ourstory Gala, themed after the film 13 Going on 30.

sections.title: Ideation + Style Guide
sections.content: What set this Ourstory Gala apart from its predecessors is that it would be a formal event held at The Great Hall, a building with high ceilings and tall glass windows. To create a brand that matched the elegance exuded by the dress code and venue, I decided to pair the classy serif Cormorant Garamond with the delicate Coneria Script. For the color palette, muted spring colors were chosen. These colors embodied the Ourstory Gala's theme of growth while also being not too flashy for a formal event. The spring palette was also ideal for the setting, as the gala would take place in March.

projects.title: We're All In This Together
projects.description: Designed a flyer and program for UCSD Asian Pacific Islander Student Association’s 23rd annual high school conference.
projects.summary: Every year, various student organizations at UC San Diego collaborate with the Student Promoted Access Center for Education and Service to host conferences that empower high school students to pursue higher education and provide them with networking opportunities. The Asian and Pacific-Islander Student Alliance's (APSA) 23rd Annual High School Conference was themed "We're All in This Together," referencing the popular Disney film, High School Musical. As head of the programming committee, I handled the branding for the conference and designed the event flyer and program.
